A Classical Era unit only available to build to Thrace, the Falxman is both stronger and weaker at the same time - while succuming to attacks on it, the Falxman is able to inflict more damage when it is attacking, making them an important offensive unit. Even if you're not at war when they come around, you're likely to need them to clear out Barbarian Encampments.

Several Balkan tribes in ancient times have developed and perfected a variety of curved weapons, reminiscent of - or even derived from - agricultural tools. The Dacian two-handed falx and one-handed sica based on a farmer's sickle, along with the Thracian rhomphaia reminiscent of a scythe, are prime examples of such weapons. Such pieces of equipment, especially the two-handed variants, possessed terrifying cutting power, mostly thanks to their size - indeed those were polearms, averaging at about 1.8 metres in length. Owing to their barbarian origin, Dacian falxmen and rhomphaia-wielding Thracians were usually unarmoured - save for a bronze helmet - and instead relied on their ferocity, speed and agility to perform devastating charges and inflict significant casualties while on the offense. For this, Thracian warriors were prized mercenaries, despite their half-barbaric outlook and the love of plunder.
Peltast

Though a ranged unit, the Peltast is very good at working on the front line - and then running away. With the powerful ability to inflict more damage on adjacent enemies, and then being able to move after attacking, the Peltast is perfect for causing damage to the enemy as well as getting away quickly.

Even though the Thracians became gradually Hellenised through trade with Greek settlements along the Black Sea coast, the Greeks themselves learned a few things from the savage Balkan tribes. Thracian military customs were one such thing. Peltasts (gr. "pelte" - light shield of curved shape) were light infantry skirmishers, whose speed and hunting skills allowed them to harass heavy, unwieldy enemy formations with deadly javelin volleys and fall back before the adversary was able to respond with his own missile troops. Clad in brightly-coloured, patterned Thracian cloaks, the nimble peltasts became synonymous with raiders and harassers. Greeks were quick to learn, and by the times of Alexander the Great employed screens of light skirmishers themselves, protecting the front of their pike phalanxes. Gradually, Greek peltasts became auxilliary melee infantry with round shields, a pair of javelins and leather armour.

The Thracians
The Odrysian Kingdom
History

Heroductus once said of the Thracians as one of the largest cultures in the world, second only to the Indians, and possibly the world’s greatest military force, if not for their decentralised system. Though his claims may have been tentious, they are certainly accurate enough to see where he was coming from; though the Thracians dominated what would become present-day Bulgaria, they rarely expanded far beyond this, despite having a vast military force. However, during its period of Balkan dominance, Thrace was unified several times; and on several occasions, they were able to spread their word far beyond their borders.
Climate and Terrain

Dominating the Balkans at the time, Thrace had a fairly diverse range of climate regions. At the northernmost borders lay the Danube Delta, in present-day Romania; to the south lay the border with the Delian League, which is roughly the same as the Bulgarian-Greek border to this day. With territories right into the heart of the Balkans, much of the Thracian territory was dominated by mountain scenes; however, most of the Thracian tribes tended to dwell in river plains, such as the Artescus.
Early History

Though the Greeks thought of the Thracians as uncivilised and barbaric, this could not have been further from the truth. While warlike, the Thracians had a thriving culture prior to their Hellenisation; many arts and crafts were already present in Thracian society before the Greeks. Akin to the Gauls in France and the Celts all over Europe, the Thracians, while culturally distinct, lived in small, fortified villages. Proper cities were almost unheard of, with the only major population centre being Seuthopolis. Most of these villages were hilltop based, allowing for extra defensive capabilities; this contrasted with the traditional tribal plains life of the area. The Greeks were early to try to colonise Thrace, founding many cities along her coast; however, Thrace, remarkably, tended to keep to the rural lifestyle it had previously had. Thrace was dominated by the Persians south of the Danube for a while as well; however, this did not deter the Thracians at all from their lifestyle.
The Thracian Kingdoms

It is unknown when exactly the Thracians rose to dominate the lands north of Greece, but by the 5th century BC, this had certainly happened. With the sudden rise in prominence, and the gradual unification of the Thracian tribes into the one kingdom, it was no doubt that they would be a truly terrifying force, and should be seen as such. In this age, the Thracians finally had a centralised government, and found that they could use this power with devastating effect, entering war after war to expand their territory further. In a few short years, the Odrysian Kingdom of Thrace was able to dominate the eastern Balkans, posing threat to many of the Greek kingdoms. In general, the Thracians were warlike, and valued it in much the same way as the likes of the Vikings later would. However, the Thracian culture only thrived further in this period; due to increased connections with the Greeks, the Thracians were able to use their knowledge to advance themselves. In Thrace, a group called the Ctistae were prominent in the field of philosophy; though not as well-known as the Greeks, they were still able to show that Thrace was going strong culturally.
Greek Influence

In the 4th century BC, Macedon’s expansion into Thracian lands caused Thrace to slowly assimilate into Greek culture; the southern part of the territory was taken by Macedon for the next century and a half. To a lesser extent, other Hellenic rulers took over parts of Thrace as part of their expansion, causing the Thracians to adopt more and more elements of Greek culture. At the same time, the Celtic culture made their way to the southern borders of Thrace, albeit never having too much of an effect on Thracian culture. These Celts later moved into Anatolia, well away from the Thracian lands. However, in the north, archaeological evidence has indicated that a Celtic subgroup, the Scordisci, lived in more or less the same area as the Thracians did, yet with little, if any conflict between them. Thrace’s borders had always been ill-defined, but they did not get more vague with the advent of other cultures assimilating themselves into the border regions of Thrace. However, with this buildup of cultural forces in the region, conflict with someone became inevitable. Though Thrace had previously been at war with Macedon, along with other Hellenic kingdoms, it had never truly lost or gained much through these wars. Now, with the borders of Thracian culture becoming less and less apparent, it became more likely that Thrace would be assimilated into another group.
Provincia Thracia

Though Thrace had been in conflict with Macedon for years, they were forced to unite when a larger enemy - the Romans - threatened the existence of both. With the growing Roman influence over the area, Macedon became part of the Roman Empire, much to the dismay of many of the inhabitants, and made those around fear that they might be the next. The Thracians resurged, fighting back against the Romans to slow, if not destroy their advance. However, a couple of the Thracian and Macedonian tribes decided to ally with the Romans instead, which only helped the Romans expand into Thrace. Slowly, Thrace was assimilated from a group of tribes to a Roman province, though the rural lifestyle of the Thracians made it harder to maintain rule over. Instead of establishing new cities in Thrace, the Romans instead placed the bulk of their military in neighbouring provinces, asserting their authority over any revolt that could take place. As the Thracians continued to back the Romans in several cases, it became apparent that assimilation was almost inevitable. After Rometalices III was murdered by his wife with no heir, the Romans were finally able to claim Thrace as part of the ever-expanding empire. Over time, the Thracians slowly adopted the Roman culture and way of life, leaving the Kingdom of Thrace lost to the mists of time.
Into Modernity

Conflict and struggle would continue to mark Thracian lands into modernity. As the Roman Empire began to collapse by the mid-5th century, much of Thrace fell into the hands of Germanic tribal rulers. Thrace's northern territory would eventually be incorporated into the first Bulgarian Empire in the 8th century. However, the surviving Eastern Roman Empire, later known as the Byzantine Empire, would continue to lay claim to Thracian lands and struggle with the Bulgarians up until the early 14th century. This period also saw raids by the Golden Horde in 1265 as well as the Catalan Company in 1307. By 1352 the Ottoman Empire began incursions into the region, subduing it within two decades and ruling for more than five centuries. The Congress of Berlin would see northern Thrace incorporated into Eastern Rumelia, and ultimately, in ten more years, reunited with Bulgaria. The rest of Thrace would be divided among Bulgaria, Greece, and Turkey at the beginning of the 20th century following the Balkan and first World War. Today, Thrace remains a geographic term used by these three states.

Thracian Factoids

"Thrace" is actually an exonym applied by the Greeks and not a native term employed by the various Thracian tribes themselves. It roughly derives from the Greek "thrasso", meaning "to stir trouble".[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The famous gladiator Spartacus was originally from Thrace before his enslavement by Rome.

King of Thrace
Ruler of the Odrysian Kingdom
History

One of the great Thracian and Odrysian kings, Sitalces came to power at a young age after losing his father to war. Though ill-equipped for leading the Thracians, Sitalces was well versed in the art of war and was able to lead his army to battle soon after his ascension to the throne, significantly expanding Thracian territory.
Rule

According to the Greek historians Herodotus and Thucydides, a royal dynasty emerged from among the Odrysian tribe in Thrace around the end of the 5th century BC, which came to dominate much of the area and peoples between the Danube and the Aegean for the next century. At the death of his father Teres I in 431 BC, Sitacles ascended the Odrysian throne. The rich state that spread from the Danube to the Aegean built roads to develop trade and trained a powerful army.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]It is said that, during the reign of Sitalces, the Odrysians could place in the field an army of 150,000, one-third of which consisted of cavalry. Sitalces immediately set out to conquer new lands for Thrace, expanding massively in the north. In 429 BC, Sitalces allied himself with the Athenians and organized a massive campaign with a vast army from independent Thracian and Paeonian tribes. Thus, Thrace became involved in the Peloponnesian War. The closest rival to Thrace was the young kingdom of Macedon, which could well have been wiped off the map at this point. With Sitalces leading the way, Thrace defeated Macedon battle after battle, slowly plowing into their ruined lands. However, Sitalces was assassinated before he could take the whole of Macedon. With no strong leader on the frontline the Thracian advance was drastically reduced, limiting the amount of land Thrace could have potentially won from the war.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Sitalces was succeeded by his nephew, Seuthes I. Seuthes' reign would directly lead to the end of the Sitalces' campaign into Macedon as Seuthes was ultimately bribed by the Macedonian king, Perdiccas II. Lacking the military aptitude of his predecessor, Seuthes would also lead an unsuccessful campaign against Athens. However, under Seuthes the Odrysian material prosperity by no means declined. It was not till after the death of Seuthes, that the power of the Odrysians rapidly waned before the rising kingdom of Macedon.
Verdict of History

Sitalces is often regarded as one of the greatest Thracian kings. His reign saw significant increases in Thracian lands, and, during which, the Odrysian power had become so threatening that Macedon sent regular tribute and entered into diplomatic marriage with Sitalces' son. He proved not only a good military leader but a shrewd diplomatic, securing an alliance with the Athenians and forcing Thracian tribes that had previously defected the Odrysian alliance to acknowledge his sovereignty.

Hail, King Sitalces, ruler of the Odrysian Kingdom of Thrace! The Thracians are an ancient people, having settled along the western coast of the Black Sea since time immemorial. Despite being regarded by some as barbarians, your people are cultured and industrious, proficient in art, music and warfare. Yet it was not until the reign of your father, Teres I, who expelled the unwelcome Persian overlords, that the bickering tribes were united under one banner to form a single Thracian kingdom. Through your political and military prowess, you expanded the boundaries of your kingdom, and threatened the very existence of fledging Macedon, which would soon grow to awe the world. During your rule, Thrace Hellenised under the influence of Greek colonists, yet it was the Greeks who adopted Thracian weapons, armour and military ideas; ideas which would even come to inspire the ever-expanding Rome herself in years to come. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Oh brave Sitalces, the tribes are divided again, and your people yearn for a leader. Will you don your armour, take up your arms and unite your people once more? Will you build a civilisation that will stand the test of time?
